chunks.text:
Referee Signals: Expulsion (Red Card)

For an expulsion, the referee shows the red card. The player must leave the playing area and cannot play for the rest of the set. An expulsion occurs for repeated unsportsmanlike conduct or a serious offense.

The signal: The referee holds the red card with an extended arm above head height. The card must be clearly visible to everyone.

media.title: Red Card - Expulsion
media.description: The referee shows the red card for player expulsion

chunks.text:
Referee Signals: Warning (Yellow Card)

For a warning, the referee shows the yellow card. This is an official warning to the player or team. The first warning has no direct consequences, but further offenses may result in penalties.

The signal: The referee holds the yellow card with an extended arm above head height.

media.title: Yellow Card - Warning
media.description: The referee shows the yellow card for a warning

chunks.text:
Referee Signals: Point (Ball In)

When the ball lands inside the court and a point is scored, the referee points with an extended arm and index finger toward the side of the team that won the point.

The signal: The arm is extended horizontally to the side, with the index finger pointing at the court of the team receiving the point.

media.title: Point - Ball In
media.description: Referee points to the side of the scoring team

chunks.text:
Referee Signals: Ball Out

When the ball lands outside the court, the referee raises both forearms vertically with open palms facing outward.

The signal: Both arms are bent at the elbows, forearms pointing upward, palms facing outward. This signals that the ball has left the playing field.

media.title: Ball Out
media.description: Referee signals the ball is out of bounds

chunks.text:
Referee Signals: Double Contact

When a player touches the ball twice in succession (except during a block), the referee shows two fingers (index and middle) pointing upward.

The signal: The arm is raised and two fingers are clearly spread and visible.

media.title: Double Contact
media.description: Two fingers indicate a double contact fault

chunks.text:
Referee Signals: Four Hits

When a team touches the ball more than three times before sending it over the net, the referee shows four fingers.

The signal: The arm is raised and four fingers are clearly spread and visible.

media.title: Four Hits
media.description: Four fingers indicate too many contacts

chunks.text:
Referee Signals: Net Touch

When a player touches the net during a playing action, the referee points to the net with the corresponding hand.

The signal: The referee touches the top of the net on the side of the offending player.

media.title: Net Touch
media.description: Referee indicates a net touch fault

chunks.text:
Referee Signals: Disqualification (Red + Yellow Cards Together)

For a disqualification, the referee shows both cards (red and yellow) together in one hand. The player must leave the playing area and competition zone and cannot participate for the rest of the match.

The signal: Both cards are held together in one hand above head height. This is the most severe penalty in volleyball.

media.title: Disqualification
media.description: Red and yellow cards together for disqualification
